urn:contentItem:4PJ1-9WN0-TX53-B1GX-00000-00Fire fight continues2007-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Fire fight continues

AUSTRALIA has offered to send specialist fire and aviation experts to Greece to help deal with the forest fire emergency, Prime Minister John Howard said.

More than 60 people have been killed since devastating fires broke out in Greece five days ago.

Mr Howard said four Australian experts could be sent. The Australian Government will donate $3 million to assist the firefighting.

urn:contentItem:5294-FD31-F0JP-W299-00000-00Bear is back in the wild2011-03-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisTELEVISIONPg. 15Bear is back in the wild

SURVIVAL expert Bear Grylls battles Alabama's freezing white waters naked, gets down and dirty with a vicious wild boar, and squeezes through some tight spots during a raging forest fire.

Grylls has served with the British Special Forces, climbed Mount Everest and explored the Arctic.

Throughout the new series he strands himself in popular wilderness destinations, where tourists often find themselves lost or in danger.

Once there, he finds his way back to civilisation, demonstrating local survival techniques along the way.

This can mean parachuting into rainforests or deserts, abseiling into valleys and climbing the highest, most inhospitable peaks around.

He encounters predators and has to forage for food from whatever he can find or hunt, including raw fish, snakes and alligators.

* On SBS, 8pm Monday.

urn:contentItem:4SVD-G100-TX5N-000X-00000-00Fires black out Athens2008-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisFOREIGNPg. 38Fires black out Athens

ATHENS: A large forest fire on the outskirts of Athens was abating yesterday after causing power outages across the Greek capital and covering it in smoke.

The blaze on Mt Hymettus,in the Glyka Nera area, damaged a major power line, causing blackouts for more than an hour in much of Athens.

It destroyed at least 100 ha of pine forest but did not threaten any homes.

Glyka Nera mayor Giorgos Siokos said he believed arsonists started the fire.

6.55pm: Ferny Creek fire hits Clarks Road.

urn:contentItem:51MJ-GJN1-DYG0-92G8-00000-00FED:Australia to help Israel fight fires2010-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:Australia to help Israel fight firesCANBERRA Dec 5

  Australia has answered Israel's call for assistance to fight bushfires which have claimed over 40 lives and razed thousands of acres of land.


   Prime Minister Julia Gillard said on Sunday a team of aviation experts would be deployed within 24 hours to help control and direct fire-fighting aircraft.
   It comes following a formal request from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to help battle the forest fire, which began last week near the northern city of Haifa.
   The team will be led by Victoria's chief fire officer Ewan Waller, who was one of those at the helm during Black Saturday.
   Australia is also making moves to provide chemical fire retardants if Israel requests for them, and will leave the door open to possibly providing more resources.

urn:contentItem:56JD-FNR1-JD34-V1Y3-00000-00MAIN HEAD2012-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisTHREEPg. 3MAIN HEADJordan Oliver

Huge plumes of smoke and ash towered above Ballarat's skyline yesterday afternoon during a large burn-off in the Canadian Forest.

Fire crews from the Country Fire Authority, Department of Sustainability and Environment and the East Victorian Forest Plantation Company controlled the 45-hectare burn yesterday inside a former blue gum plantation.

Owners of the plantation, EVFPC, used their own fire fighting appliances to help control the burn and teamed up with those from the DSE and the CFA.

Fifteen CFA units from Ballarat, Sebastopol and Buninyong attended the fire, along with four DSE firefighting members and eight EVFPC staff.

Beginning at 1pm, the fire took just over five hours to burn the majority of the plantation's remains.

CFA Grampians region vegetation reduction officer Tony Brady said "near perfect" weather conditions provided a good opportunity to reduce fuel loads before the fire season.

"It's also a really timely reminder for people to begin preparing their properties and get ready for the upcoming fire season," he said.

Authorities warned smoke may remain in the area for some time.

urn:contentItem:49NY-M290-01S8-D1CP-00000-00<published>1995-08-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:03:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ARSON SUSPECTED IN WILD BUSH FIRE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">EASTPORT, New York - About 400 evacuees were allowed home yesterday as firefighters cleaned up a wind-driven forest fire that threatened high-priced beach resort communities.And about 40 firefighters suffered minor injuries.</p><p>Authorities said the 2400ha blaze looked like arson, and critics asked why federal airplanes that were to bomb the fire with water did not arrive until yesterday.Officials, however, would not declare the fire contained. The area has not had rain in 19 days.The blaze, feeding on tinder-dry pines and oaks about 110km east of New York City, destroyed one home and a lumber yard, damaged seven other homes and a train station, and shut down railroads and roadways.Tourist business was also getting back to normal on the summer's penultimate weekend, as visitors returned to expensive summer homes and resorts.-APEND OF urn:contentItem:57J1-W501-JC0X-K114-00000-00NSW:Barringella Creek bushfire downgraded2013-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSNSW:Barringella Creek bushfire downgradedLisa MartinNOWRA, NSW Jan 18

  A Nowra rural property owner has been taken to hospital after fire swept through a farm and destroyed a shed on the town's outskirts.


   Emergency warnings for bushfire burning 12km southwest of Nowra at Barringella Creek were downgraded on Friday evening, RFS commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons told ABC Radio.
   Residents in that area have been told to "watch and act".
   RFS logistics officer Robyn Bolton told AAP firefighters were concerned fire on the south side of Shoalhaven River around Yalwal Road could threaten properties along the river at Burrier and Coolendel.
   She said five crews that had been patrolling a forest fire at Wandandian rushed off to lend a hand.
   "They weren't able to get into a property that was in trouble," she said, before 80km winds came through from the south at 5pm (AEDT).
   "There's certainly been a shed lost and the owner of the property was taken to hospital by ambulance."
   Ms Bolton said if a westerly wind came through there was a danger the fire could jump the Shoalhaven River to the north side.
   "If it crosses the river and we get a westerly switch it could sweep through a lot of residences," she said.

urn:contentItem:57FS-TV81-F0J6-J2D8-00000-00THERE was no way Kristine Cook was going to work yesterday2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5THERE was no way Kristine Cook was going to work yesterday

THERE was no way Kristine Cook was going to work yesterday morning.

The Dartmoor mother knew if she went to work at a dairy over the border in South Australia she might not be able to return home.

An air of uncertainty still hung over Dartmoor yesterday and Ms Cook's worst fear was that a wall of fire would separate her from her two sons at home. "A lot of people left on Monday," Ms Cook said.

"I'm confident about staying here.

"I know two families that have left, one here and one in Mumbannar."

She joined about 100 others in the Dartmoor Community Hall yesterday looking for answers about the movements of the monster blaze. By her side her two sons, Callum, 17, and Ashley, 18, waited to hear if their town was in danger. The forest fire had disrupted their plans for summer dirt biking around Darmoor's many forest trails.

"It's been a bit hectic," Callum said.

While fire trucks had taken over the Dartmoor football oval much of the town had fallen silent.

"If we see flames then we'll head," Callum said.

urn:contentItem:57FS-TV81-F0J6-J2B2-00000-00THERE was no way Kristine Cook was going to work yesterday2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5THERE was no way Kristine Cook was going to work yesterday

THERE was no way Kristine Cook was going to work yesterday morning.

The Dartmoor mother knew if she went to work at a dairy over the border in South Australia she might not be able to return home.

An air of uncertainty still hung over Dartmoor yesterday and Ms Cook's worst fear was that a wall of fire would separate her from her two sons at home. "A lot of people left on Monday," Ms Cook said.

"I'm confident about staying here.

"I know two families that have left, one here and one in Mumbannar."

She joined about 100 others in the Dartmoor Community Hall yesterday looking for answers about the movements of the monster blaze. By her side her two sons, Callum, 17, and Ashley, 18, waited to hear if their town was in danger. The forest fire had disrupted their plans for summer dirt biking around Darmoor's many forest trails.

"It's been a bit hectic," Callum said.

While fire trucks had taken over the Dartmoor football oval much of the town had fallen silent.

"If we see flames then we'll head," Callum said.

urn:contentItem:51MR-WWY1-JCVT-J3P5-00000-00Supertanker to fight fire2010-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSIn Brief OverseasPg. 7Supertanker to fight fireISRAEL

HAIFA. Dozens of firefighting planes from around the world are in the skies over the deadly Israeli forest fire, and a giant US aircraft is set to join the battle, along with help from Australia. As fires sweep through the hills around the northern city of Haifa for a fourth day, hopes are high that the arrival of a rented Boeing Supertanker, the largest firefighting plane in the world, will tip the balance against the biggest fire in Israel's 62-year history. The fire, racing through pine forests on Carmel hill ridge, has killed 41 people and forced more than 17,000 from their homes. Help is coming from Australia, with Prime Minister Julia Gillard saying her government is sending firefighters, including some with expertise from last year's Black Saturday bushfires.

urn:contentItem:7WRW-M7J0-Y9B7-51FG-00000-00Qld: Aircraft on standby to water bomb fires2009-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQld: Aircraft on standby to water bomb firesBRISBANE Oct 1

  Aircraft remain on standby to continue water bombing a fire in central Queensland while a number of other fires continue to burn across the state.
   Fire crews have saved a number of homes at Captain Creek, near Agnes Water after a fire broke out on Tuesday.
   Aerial reconnaissance has helped fire crews contain a forest fire in the north coast region and statewide backburning operations continue to prevent the spread of grass fires.
   Fires continue to burn at Mundoolun, Mt Moffat, St Mary, Moolboolaman, Captain Creek, Mt Morgan, Tungamull, and Bemerside.
   No homes are under threat.
   Fire bans remain in place across the state until midnight on October 5.

urn:contentItem:7XVT-HY60-YBDY-R43K-00000-00US fire experts in Otways2010-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4US fire experts in OtwaysJESSICA CRAVEN

A CRACK team of North American bushfire experts will help fight fires in the Otways.

Seventeen forest fire experts arrived in Victoria to replace the 15 who have spent the past month based in fire hot spots across the state.

Two firefighters, Miriam Morrill and George Sheppard, will be based at Colac.

Department of Sustainability and Environment Otways district manager Andrew Morrow said the firefighters in the first contingent, including Colac-based Jeff Gardetto and Mark Struble, made a valuable contribution to DSE's firefighting efforts.

``We welcome this new team as it arrives to continue that good work and give the existing crew a spell after a month of hard work,'' he said.

The experts have skills in water bombing, burn-offs and field operations.

urn:contentItem:538F-PH11-F0JP-W427-00000-00Start the day with a laugh2011-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisJOKESPg. 32Start the day with a laugh

A PHOTOGRAPHER for a national magazine was assigned to get photos of a great forest fire.

Smoke at the scene was too thick to get any good shots, so he frantically called his home office to hire a plane.

``It will be waiting for you at the airport!'' he was assured by his editor.

As soon as he got to the rural airport, sure enough, a plane was warming up near the runway.

He jumped in with his equipment and yelled, ``Let's go! Let's go!''

The pilot swung the plane into the wind and soon they were in the air. ``Fly over the north side of the fire,'' said the photographer, ``and make three or four low level passes.''

``Why?'' asked the pilot.

``Because I'm going to take pictures! I'm a photographer!'' said the photographer with great exasperation.

After a long pause the pilot said, ``You mean you're not the instructor?''

urn:contentItem:7V5M-05R0-YBDY-R0S4-00000-00Arson killer guilty2009-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 31Arson killer guilty

A MAN who started a deadly Californian forest fire that claimed the lives of five firefighters has been found guilty of murder, local prosecutors confirmed.

Raymond Oyler, 38, was convicted of five first-degree murder counts relating to an October 2006 fire that scorched more than 17,400ha and destroyed more than 50 houses and buildings.

The verdicts came after a six-week trial in Riverside, 90km east of Los Angeles.

Prosecutors said during the case Oyler was a man ``bent on destruction'' who started the fire out of anger that his dog had been impounded.

He could face the death penalty when the sentencing phase of the trial begins next week.

urn:contentItem:7YKP-PFT0-YBDY-R144-00000-00Canada fires flare2010-05-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 33Canada fires flareCANADA Montreal, Thursday

SOME 800 firefighters were dispatched today to Quebec's outback to combat more than a dozen forest fires raging north of Montreal.

Most went to the Haute-Mauricie region 400km north of Quebec to douse a dozen blazes.

Thick smoke swept over the Wemotaci native reservation, forcing more than 1300 to evacuate their homes overnight.

Several dozen people were evacuated from the Obedjiwan reserve, near La Tuque, Quebec.

Four of the fires were out of control in dry forests after a record heat wave, Marie-Louise Harvey, spokeswoman for Quebec's forest fire fighting agency, Sopfeu, said. Firefighters on the ground were being supported by aerial water bombers.

Authorities have forbidden lighting campfires through most of the province.

Two other fires erupted in the Abitibi region, near Ontario, Sopfeu spokeswoman Joanie Cote said.

In ageing, one becomes more foolish and more wise - Francois, Duc de La Rochefoucauld, French author (1613-1680)

Helicopters fight a massive forest fire affecting the commune of Quillon, in southern Chile's Bio Bio region, some 500 Km south of Santiago, on January 3, 2012. Forest fires in southern Chile, fueled by intense heat and strong winds, advanced further Tuesday after destroying nearly 40,000 hectares (100,000 acres), officials said. The worst of the blazes were concentrated in Chile's Bio Bio region, where about 22,500 hectares have been destroyed, according to Chile's National Emergency Office (Onemi). About 500 people have been evacuated from the area and 162 homes destroyed. The damage prompted the authorities to declare the region a "disaster zone," which will allow residents to receive federal emergency assistance. The Chilean government has asked Brazil for an aircraft that can carry water to extinguish flames. urn:contentItem:4R5D-X9J0-TXDB-G1CK-00000-00Bushfire fight continues2007-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisBushfire fight continues

Fire crews now have control of a forest fire in Tasmania's north east, but a blaze is still burning uncontrolled in a South West Wilderness Area.

Two helicopters had been helping to fight the fire on Forestry Tasmania land next to the Tasman Highway near Scottsdale.

A mopping-up operation has started and the helicopters have been stood down from the fire, which fire fighters believe was started by a cigarette butt.

The other fire near Maydena has now burned more than 400 hectares.

Fire crews believe a lightning strike started the blaze near the Adamsfield Track.

urn:contentItem:7XF3-5CB1-2RG7-300P-00000-00Campers escape fire near Yarrawonga2009-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisCampers escape fire near Yarrawonga

Several Murray River campers had a lucky escape from a forest fire west of Yarrawonga yesterday afternoon.

Twelve fire tankers were called to the fire at Jim's Island Track about 2:00pm AEDT.

It was put out after burning less than a hectare.

Regional CFA duty officer David Harris says it is unclear if campers or campfires were responsible.

But he says forest fires have more potential to threaten lives because more people are camping at this time of year.

"There were a number of campers in the area at the time and luckily a lot of them had mobile phones and had the means to contact the fire services," Mr Harris said.

"It's probably a timely reminder, particularly coming into this New Year's period, [people] need to be very aware of their use of fire."

urn:contentItem:4N3R-18P0-TX52-M20N-00000-00Nice one2007-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Nice one

Jumping out of an aeroplane might seem scary enough. But how about parachuting into a raging forest fire for just two dollars an hour? US man Gary Buck admits he was really scared when he made his first drop as a ''smokejumper'' back in 1966. Buck spent 17 summers parachuting to fight bushfires. Now he's leading the effort to convert an old smokejumpers' base near Cave Junction, Oregon, into a museum. US Forest Service smokejumpers went on to become everything from attorneys to astronauts and Buck adds they were all real characters, too.

urn:contentItem:53RV-7441-JC0X-K07W-00000-00NSW:Man approaches boy near forest entrance2011-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSNSW:Man approaches boy near forest entranceSYDNEY Sept 9

  A boy has been approached by a man near a forest fire trail north of Sydney who allegedly tried to lure him away by telling him his mother had been hurt.


   Police say they are looking for the man after he approached the 12-year-old at the entrance of the forest at Mount Colah and told him his mother was injured.
   The boy had been walking along Flinders Place when he was approached by the man at about 3.50pm (AEST) on Thursday.
   Police say the man asked the boy to go with him because his mother was injured.
   The boy ran away and told his parents, sparking a police hunt.
   The man is described as being aged between 20 and 25, of Caucasian appearance, and between 160-165cm tall.
   He was wearing a long sleeve black hooded top and light coloured shorts at the time of the incident.
   He is further described as having muscular legs and prominent lips.
   Anyone with information about his identity is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:7X8K-SHK0-Y9B7-5085-00000-00Qld: Severe fire danger forecasted for Qld2009-12-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQld: Severe fire danger forecasted for QldBRISBANE Dec 9

  The Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) has forecast severe grassland and forest fire danger for the Darling Downs and Granite Belt district.


   Temperatures of up to 41 degrees with relative humidity down to 10 per cent are forecasted for the region.
   A Department of Community Safety (DCS) spokesman also said they were expecting 30km/h northwest to northerly winds.
   The dangerous fire conditions has prolonged fire bans in Toowoomba, Southern Downs, Western Downs and Goondiwindi.
   Two under control fires are currently burning in southern Queensland, one at Biarra and another north of Laidley.
   Queensland Fire and Rescue Service has also extended the fire bans in the local government areas of Rockhampton, Banana, Gladstone, Bundaberg, North Burnett, Fraser Coast, Cherbourg and Gympie.
   Fire bans will remain in place for these areas until December 14.

urn:contentItem:7X4J-B230-Y9Y8-T0JY-00000-00No relief for sweltering Gippsland2009-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisNo relief for sweltering Gippsland

Another extremely hot day is in store for Gippsland residents in south-east Victoria today.

Parts of the region, including Orbost, were the hottest in the state at times yesterday.

Late storms, lightning and temperatures as high as 40 degrees are forecast for parts of East Gippsland today.

A top of 35 is forecast for the Latrobe Valley and 39 is forecast for Bairnsdale.

The forest fire danger across the region is rated very high.

The Country Fire Authority advises people who live in a bushfire prone area and plan to leave, should evacuate this morning.

Residents who have decided to stay should only do so if their home is well prepared and can be actively defended.

The weather bureau is predicting a stronger cool change will begin moving across the state this afternoon.

urn:contentItem:51M7-8GG1-F0JP-W37B-00000-00Fire kills jailers2010-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 34Fire kills jailers

A BUS burst into flames as it raced to an Israeli prison during a massive forest fire, killing dozens of prison guards participating in the rescue mission.

Officials said it was one of the deadliest accidents in the nation's history.

Fire officials say the blaze, which torched about 650ha, remained out of control after nightfall.

A university, three prisons and a hospital were evacuated and at least one village was destroyed.

After nightfall, bodies of 25 victims from the bus had been identified, police said.

Fire officials said about 40 people were killed. About two dozen people were still missing, Israel Radio reported.

"This is a disaster of unprecedented proportions," Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said.

He said the government was using all means at its disposal to contain the blaze, and he appealed to Cyprus, Italy, Russia and Greece to provide support.

Greece and Cyprus have agreed to send firefighting helicopters.

After nightfall, Netanyahu flew over the scene and later said the blaze was of "international proportions".

urn:contentItem:51MS-FR01-JCM0-601K-00000-00Grassland fire risk in parts of NSW2010-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisGrassland fire risk in parts of NSW

The summer fire risk is moving from the forests to the grasslands in south-eastern Australia.

Widespread rain has reduced the risk of forest fire, but the past week's rain of 100 to 250 millimetres has grass up to the bellies of cattle on the Monaro and south coast of NSW.

Rural Fire Service regional manager John Cullen says there's not enough livestock to keep grass down after prolonged drought forced destocking on farms.

"Last season, we had fires rolling around at this time of year," he said.

"Last year we had no feed in the open country, and we would have encouraged fire into the open country where we could deal with it.

"This year is a different game. We are going to have, depending what happens after Christmas, a bulk of feed in the open country and we are getting into grass fire firefighting where fires will move quickly in that open country."

urn:contentItem:4R5D-X9J0-TXDB-G19T-00000-00Heat hampers firefighting in Barmah Forest2007-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisHeat hampers firefighting in Barmah Forest

Fire crews are fighting a blaze in the Barmah State Forest, north west of Shepparton.

The fire is believed to have been caused by a lightning strike yesterday.

Parks Victoria Incident Controller, Scott Armstrong says the 2 hectare fire is hard to get to.

He says the hot weather today could make controlling the blaze very difficult.

"The area that it's in, there are significant fuel loads in there, given the predictions for the weather today, certainly we were talking about a scenario later this afternoon, yes there's a lot of potential there to become much larger," he said.

urn:contentItem:511J-0JX1-F0JP-W17W-00000-00Fast news2010-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 36Fast news

Lee picks PM

SEOUL: South Korean President Lee Myung-bak has picked the head of the state audit board as his new prime minister after a previous nominee quit over claims of misconduct. Kim Hwang-sik, 62, currently heads the Board of Audit and Inspection, a body overseeing the conduct of government agencies.

California on alert

LOS ANGELES: Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger declared a state of emergency yesterday in California as hundreds of residents in small mountain communities were told to evacuate because of a forest fire in the southern Sierra Nevada. The fire erupted on Sunday in the Lower Kern River Canyon.

Man sues over fat

LONDON: A man who lost half his weight after gastric band surgery was preparing to sue the National Health Service yesterday, claiming he would rather be fat again. Tim Daily, 47, said he weighed 152kg before undergoing surgery to reduce his stomach capacity. The Buckinghamshire man claims he now faces a lifetime of agony and being fed through a tube.

urn:contentItem:54FS-9H01-JD67-12X9-00000-00Prepare now for fire season2011-12-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 16Prepare now for fire season

THE challenge for fire authorities this summer is complacency. This week homes in 12 Border and North East towns will find a booklet in their mailbox detailing the potential fire threat, places to go, things to do in either a grass or forest fire. But these same people head into a summer where the fire danger threat has already been diluted by storms and mild weather. It comes just a year after the second-wettest summer on record. For those willing to dismiss the threat just two summers after Black Saturday, that horrendous firestorm followed a fortnight of 40-degree days but most significantly there was a relatively mild start to the season. Paddocks and hills were still green at Christmas 2008, just as they are likely to be this festive season. The information provided in these booklets provide clear warnings and highlights to the need for people to understand the danger. It is pointless to be reaching for the handbook and the hose at the same time. People in towns singled out ahead of the fire season should study the information and know what they will do in an emergency.

AN internationally recognised expert on bushfires has attacked the lack of support from the State Government and says its ''absurd'' regulations are hampering the work of firefighters.

Former chief fire officer Athol Hodgson said the bushfires raging across Victoria should have been dealt with when they first broke out.

''Failing to make an immediate attack with sufficient force is the first cardinal sin of fire fighting,'' said Mr Hodgson, who is president of Forest Fire Victoria.

Mr Hodgson said little or nothing had been done to reduce undergrowth.

urn:contentItem:7WB1-CB80-YBDY-R04D-00000-00Front seat for wildfire2009-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisFOREIGNPg. 34Front seat for wildfire

VANCOUVER: When nature has unleashed its worst, sometimes there's nothing you can do but sit back and watch.

That's exactly what this group of helicopter pilots did - pulling up chairs to take in the fury of a forest fire devouring large swaths of British Columbia in Canada.

The pilots were watching as a controlled fire burned on Mt McLean in a desperate attempt to reduce the amount of fuel for a wildfire burning on the mountain beside the town of Lillooet.

More than 2500 people were forced from their homes as a fire raged less than 1.6km away. Another 120 people in nearby Brooksmere also were evacuated.

In all, 3000 people have been evacuated since Sunday and 85 per cent of British Columbia remains on high alert as lightning strikes and tinder-dry forests continue to fuel the wildfires on Canada's Pacific coast.

urn:contentItem:4PJW-H3M0-TX52-X1B9-00000-005 firemen killed on island2007-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisWORLD BRIEFINGPg. 345 firemen killed on island

FIVE firefighters died and 14 were injured as they were encircled by a forest fire on Croatia's central island of Kornati, the state-run news agency and other local media reported yesterday.

Police in the nearby city of Sibenik confirmed only that 14 firefighters were injured at the island of Kornat and there was no immediate official confirmation of the deaths, which were reported by HINA, the state-run Croatian TV and two other channels.

Of the 14 injured, four are in a life-threatening condition, according to a doctor on duty at a local clinic. The fire was still raging on the island.

urn:contentItem:7V00-KVG0-Y9Y8-S19W-00000-00Death toll rises in fire-ravaged Gippsland2009-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisDeath toll rises in fire-ravaged Gippsland

The death toll from the bushfires burning in Gippsland, east of Melbourne, now stands at 17.

Assessment crews have been sifting through the ruins from the fire that swept from Churchill in the Latrobe Valley into the Strzlecki Ranges to an area known as the Jeeralangs.

The highest toll was in the tiny community of Callignee where 10 people died. Five died at Hazelwood and two at Jeeralang.

Fire activity has decreased overnight and some areas have had showers of rain.

Community meetings are being held in towns north of the fire tonight as the fire front remains uncontained and is expected to move slowly north.

The Bunyip Forest Fire is also still burning in the direction of Neerim Junction, north of Warragul.

The Princes Highway has reopened this morning and Gippsland train services are returning to normal.

urn:contentItem:7TYJ-NFW0-Y9Y8-S0YT-00000-00SA bushfire conditions 'as bad as 2005'2009-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:04ZLexisNexisSA bushfire conditions 'as bad as 2005'

The Country Fire Service in South Australia is bracing for what it says are the worst fire conditions since the deadly 2005 Eyre Peninsula bushfires.

Wind gusts of up to 90 kilometres per hour are predicted, along with temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius.

It was already 37C in Adelaide at 9:00am ACDT.

More than 10,000 firefighters and 11 water bombers are on stand-by in strategic positions around the state.

One water bomber has already been sent to help contain a forest fire at Nangwarry near Mount Gambier.

National parks at Mount Lofty and on the Fleurieu Peninsula are closed because of the bushfire threat, and Monarto Zoo is also closed.

The SES emergency number is 132 500 and the South Australian Country Fire Service information hotline is 1300 362 361.
